title: Expert: A 'good parent' doesn't have to pay for college
text:
You’re not a bad parent if you save for retirement instead of paying your child’s way through college. It’s a toxic myth that Sarah Newcomb, director of behavior science at Morningstar, wants to debunk.

“We’re so used to sacrificing for our children – sometimes we can even make that a point of pride,” she said recently on Yahoo Finance. “But if you sacrifice your retirement savings to send your child to college, you’re making a huge mistake.”

Parents can miss out on earning tens of thousands of dollars over 20 years if they put their dollars toward their children’s education rather than in their 401(k) or other retirement plans, according to a recent report from Morningstar, an investment analysis firm.

For instance, if you invest $10,000 at a 6% interest rate, you can build up $42,000 in retirement savings after 20 years. Even an investment of $10,000 at a smaller 4% return rate could more than double in the same time span.

Benjamin Philip, 23, a graduate in engineering from The City College of New York poses for photos with his family at his commencement ceremony. (Photo: REUTERS/Gabriela Bhaskar) More

That’s much-needed money for many Americans who are already woefully behind on saving for retirement. And unlike for college, there’s no loan you can take out for retirement, Newcomb said.

Emotional trap

“There’s this belief we have that a ‘good parent’ pays for college,” Newcomb said. “And if you believe that, then no financial advice is going to help you because not paying for college means you’re a bad parent.”

But by succumbing to this emotional trap, parents not only hurt themselves. They could potentially harm their child, too, in the long run.

“You can burden them now while they’re young and healthy and able to repay [the loans],” Newcomb said. “Or, you can burden them later when you need to move in with them because you didn’t prepare for retirement.”

Still, she acknowledged that parents rightly worry about student loan debt, which has reached a staggering $1.48 trillion and is stifling for many who have taken out loans. Some borrowers report having to delay major life milestones, such as getting married or buying a house because of their education debt.

Graduates of The City College of New York walk to their seats at their commencement ceremony in Manhattan. (Photo: REUTERS/Gabriela Bhaskar) More

The kids are alright

But as long as loan payments are 8% or less than their starting salary after graduation, students should be able to shoulder the debt obligation, Newcomb said. To keep loan amounts down, Newcomb also recommended that students work while in school.

She noted that students who work up to 15 hours a week actually perform better in their studies.

“You don’t have to feel guilty having your child doing work study,” Newcomb said. “It can actually increase engagement, increase performance, and increase quality of life.”

Dhara is a writer for Yahoo Finance. Follow her on Twitter @dsinghx.

description: Parents can miss out on earning tens of thousands of dollars if they put their dollars toward their child's education rather than retirement.
